model_response: The study is designed as a phase 1 open-label, two-arm study. The study participants will be randomized in either the drug combination group or the control group. Participants assigned to the drug combination group will receive Ziv-aflibercept plus Cemiplimab. Participants assigned to the control group will receive Ziv-Aflibercept alone or placebo (which is an inactive substance that is similar to Cemiplimab) plus Cemiplimab in the same dose.

The combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept is an experimental treatment, and there is no prior experience with treating metastatic uveal melanoma using these two agents in combination. Therefore, in the absence of any data on the best dosing schedule of these agents, the schedule chosen is based on the pharmacodynamics (PD) and pharmacokinetics (PK) characteristics of the individual Ziv-Aflibercept and Cemiplimab drugs. PK and PD data from single-agent studies with Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept are being evaluated to determine the optimal dosing schedule for each drug. This combination trial design was chosen based on the PK and PD profiles of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept when administered individually. Studies showed that Cemiplimab PK is not impacted when it is administered along with other concomitant anticancer agents, and its maximum serum concentrations are not affected by other coadministered drugs. Therefore, the schedule of Cemiplimab being given every 3 weeks was deemed suitable. Studies also showed that when Ziv-Aflibercept is given along with other agents, its Cmax (the maximum plasma concentration that is achieved during the first dosing interval for a drug) is approximately two-fold higher than when Ziv-Aflibercept is given alone. Therefore, the schedule of Ziv-Aflibercept being given every 2 weeks was deemed suitable.

As with any experimental treatment, the combination therapy used in this study may cause adverse effects in some participants. However, the goal of the study is to determine the safety and efficacy of the treatment, so the potential benefits outweigh the risks. The clinical trial also involves regular monitoring of participants to ensure the safety of the treatment and identify any potential side effects. The reasoning behind the design of the experimental arm is to evaluate the short-term clinical effectiveness of Ghrelin in patients with acute stroke. The study arm comprises two phases, as per the protocol outlined in the trial: the acute phase from hospital admission until 5 days after hospitalization and the post-acute phase from 6 days to 90 days after hospitalization. In the acute phase, administration of Ghrelin is designed to promote early neurological restoration and functional recovery. The daily frequency and dosage of Ghrelin were selected by referring to previous clinical trials and pharmacological studies. The length of treatment and follow-up period were set by considering the timeframe for spontaneous neurological recovery and the longest period where the potential effects from Ghrelin could be assessed in the post-acute phase.

The control group will be labeled as "Control: Standard care". This group will consist of patients who receive standard care, which will differ depending on their admission status. Stroke patients who are admitted within six hours of onset will receive standard care with intravenous alteplase. Stroke patients who are presented to the ED after six hours will receive standard care with EVT if indicated for their condition.

The intervention/treatment for the control group will be standard care for stroke, including intravenous thrombolysis if indicated. The standard treatment does not include Ghrelin or any other hormone-based or nutritional intervention.

The control group, who will receive standard care for the treatment of stroke, will serve as a benchmark to compare the efficacy and safety of Ghrelin in the experimental group. This will allow us to assess whether the addition of Ghrelin treatment can improve the outcomes of stroke patients undergoing endovascular thrombectomy (EVT).

Patients randomized to Group 1 (DCCV + PVI) will undergo general anesthesia with either a femoral or a tibial access, followed by DC cardioversion and pulmonary vein isolation (PVI: circumferential ablation lines at antral and left anterior of each vein) using a three-dimensional electroanatomical mapping system. During the procedure, heparin will be administered targeting a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) at 60–80 seconds and maintaining the electrode catheter in the pulmonary veins with the patient on continuous electrocardiographic (ECG) monitoring. For the narrow implants, the initial surgical phase of the implant placement will follow the regular protocol, with the placement of standard bone level Rex three-piece implants with an insertion torque above 35 Ncm. I think we could design another study arm focusing on radioligand therapy (RLT). We could call it "Concurrent treatment (RLT/EBRT): Radioligand Therapy + External Beam Radiotherapy". This arm would involve the injection of RLT and subsequent external beam radiotherapy to deliver radiation doses. The goal would be to determine if this concurrent radioligand and radiation therapy would enhance antitumor effects by damaging tumor glands directly with radiation and at the same time increasing radiation dose by the action of RLT. The advantage of treating at an earlier stage is the reduced likelihood of encountering barriers to the treatment of cancer such as inflammation or scar tissue formation, which may lead to a better response to treatment. This arm would help us compare and identify potential improvements that may result from the addition of radioligand therapy. Let me know if you have any further requirements or specifications for this study arm.

In the second study arm, patients will receive the same treatment as the first arm (external beam radiotherapy followed by 177Lu-rhPSMA-10 radioligand therapy) plus additional radiotherapy in the form of 177Lu-PSMA-617 radioligand therapy (EBRT, 177Lu-rhPSMA-10, and 177Lu-PSMA-617). As the second arm will build upon the previous trial arm, we can refer to this arm as "Early Dual β "-EBRT, 177Lu-rhPSMA-10, and 177Lu-PSMA-617. The rationale for this arm is to investigate the potential increase in therapeutic efficacy with the addition of 177Lu-PSMA-617 radioligand therapy. Additionally, the use of biospecimen collection and functional imaging allows for monitoring of treatment response and side effects.

Yes, that is correct! I would recommend a slightly modified exclusion criterion: patients should not have any contraindications to radiotherapy (including active inflammatory bowel disease or prior pelvic radiotherapy or prior radioligand therapy) or any risk factors for lum-177PSMA therapy (baseline >= grade 2 myelosuppression, renal insufficiency or xerostomia), definitive findings of systemic metastasis, unacceptable medical or radiation safety risk, unmanageable urinary tract obstruction or hydronephrosis or severe acute co-morbidities. Each heating pad size will cover a maximum of an 8 cm×8 cm area of the hands and feet. The temperature will be regulated within the range of 37°C to 38°C. Each participant will receive hot compress packs approximately 15 minutes before the infusion and for 30 minutes following the completion of the infusion. The main aim of using hot compresses is to prevent vasospasms of the hands or feet, and this is also commonly used as a nursing care after surgery. The warm temperature can increase blood flow and reduce the possibility of vasospasms, and this was observed by a study published in the International Nursing Journal, which found that using hot compress therapy and gentle massages could help prevent vasospasms in the patient's extremities that were likely to occur after surgery . Cold compress treatment is an effective nursing care procedure used in postoperative recovery and for the treatment of inflammatory diseases in medical care . Based on this, the use of cold compresses is expected to significantly reduce pain in this study.

The hot compressing group will receive interventions of temperature control within the range of 37-38 °C. In the Eun et al. study, the hot compresses were conducted once a week for 8 consecutive weeks and only included one intervention during the chemotherapy period. On the other hand, our study involves hot compresses conducted twice a week for 20 minutes, along with two applications at the beginning and end of the Oxaliplatin infusion.

In the cold compressing group, patients will receive cold compress interventions on their hands and feet. The temperature control will be maintained within the range of 12-18 degrees Celsius. model_response: Phase 4 of a clinical trial is known as the evaluation or post-marketing phase. This phase is not a formal requirement for marketing approval, but it is conducted voluntarily and can last for many years. It involves ongoing monitoring of the drug's safety and effectiveness in actual patients, who may have varying characteristics from those studied in Phase 3 trials. The phase is also known as the drug utilization assessment phase, as it allows the assessment of how a drug is used in the real-world setting. Phase 4 trials are performed after a drug has been approved and marketed for use, and there is substantial evidence indicating that many drugs are evaluated differently under real-world conditions compared to clinical trial settings.

model_response: Thank you for the inclusion and exclusion criteria. In terms of the study type for this trial, it sounds like the study falls under a randomized controlled trial (RCT). RCTs are characterized by their prospective design, which involves randomly assigning research participants to one of two (or sometimes more) interventions to systematically test the effects of each intervention compared to the others. RCTs provide the strongest evidence for the effectiveness of an intervention, but the study design also has strict criteria for inclusion. These criteria ensure that the study group and control group are similar enough to be considered comparable and that any differences that arise are directly related to the intervention. In summary, the study aims to develop and test a treatment prognosis calculator for identifying US military veterans with suicidal ideation who are likely to respond well to the current standard of care treatment and which service members should receive brief cognitive behavioral therapy (BCBT) as a first-line treatment. The study will offer both the Treatment as usual (TAU) and Brief Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (BCBT) arms, with the former including routine suicide risk screening and assessment, safety planning with means restriction, and the Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS) approach, while the latter involves 12 outpatient individual psychotherapy sessions, divided into three phases, focusing on assessment of suicidal behaviors, crisis response planning, cognitive restructuring, and relapse prevention. The goal of including the TAU arm is to establish a baseline for comparison, understand the effectiveness of the current standard of care treatment in reducing suicidal ideation, and evaluate the performance of the treatment prognosis calculator in predicting response to TAU and identifying those who may not respond well. On the other hand, the BCBT arm serves to assess the effectiveness of this treatment as an alternative for those who do not respond well to TAU, and also validate the treatment prognosis calculator to guide personalized treatment decisions and assess its ability to predict treatment response. By including both study arms, the researchers hope to develop and test a treatment prognosis calculator for guiding personalized treatment decisions, thereby aiming to address the existing problems of lack of standardized, data-driven treatment algorithms and high rates of suicide among US military veterans with SI.

model_response: I apologize for the confusion. We have already included the intervention/treatment that the participants will receive. The intervention/treatment is ICI201 CAR-T cell injection. Is there something else you'd like to add?

Certainly! ICI201 is a CAR-T cell therapy, which involves two steps. The first step is apheresis, in which T lymphocytes are collected from the patient's peripheral blood. The collection of these cells typically involves blood draws ranging from 500 ml to 1.5 L, depending on the number of lymphocytes needed. This step may also involve leukapheresis, which involves passing the patient's peripheral blood through a machine to separate the T lymphocytes. Once the cells are removed from the patient's blood, they are then modified using transduction to generate a final CAR-T cell therapy product. The second step is the infusion of the modified T cells into the patient. During the infusion phase, the patient may experience side effects such as cytokine release syndrome, which can be managed with supportive care measures such as fluids, antimicrobial prophylaxis, and the use of corticosteroid or tocilizumab to suppress the systemic inflammatory response. A complete infusion will be given on Day 1 and, if the participant's condition is stable, Day 2. The initial dose will be 5 × 107 CAR T cells. The CAR (chimeric antigen receptor) is a type of molecule that contains a targeting domain, which is a type of protein that binds to a specific antigen on the surface of cancer cells, and an effector domain that is a type of protein that activates the immune system. In the case of ICI201, the targeting domain is a single-chain variable fragment that binds to multiple myeloma cells and the effector domain is an intracellular signaling domain of the TCRβ protein that activates T cells. Overall, CAR-T cell therapy has been found to be effective for patients with multiple myeloma who have relapsed after receiving conventional treatments. The ICI201 CAR T cell product is currently being evaluated in phase 1 study after administration of the cells

Correct! We are conducting an open-label, single group assignment, single arm trial with no masking, evaluating the safety and efficacy of ICI201 CAR-T cell injection in patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The EUS-guided gallbladder drainage will be performed via transparietal or transgastroduodenal approach depending on the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of the approach in individual patients. For transparietal approach, the gastric wall will be first punctured using a 19-gauge needle, followed by gallbladder infusion of saline solution or a contrast medium diluted with saline solution. Next, the needle will be re-inserted into the gallbladder to access the papilla and will be replaced with a wire under fluoroscopic and ultrasound guidance. The delivery sheath will then be introduced along the wire over a tension wire. A 10- or 16-mm LAMS will then be deployed into the gallbladder under EUS and fluoroscopic guidance. For transgastroduodenal approach, the cystic duct and common bile duct will be punctured first, followed by the insertion of a 4-mm nasobiliary drainage catheter. Finally, a LAMS will be deployed into the gallbladder at the inflection point where the infundibulum joins the fundus of the gallbladder.

model_response: The experimental arm in this trial is called "Internet-Behavioral Cough Suppression Therapy" (iBCST). It is a 15-week-long treatment that will be delivered via an online app/website. Participants assigned to the experimental arm will watch 14 educational and training videos on the website as recommended. Each video is 1 to 10 minutes long. Participants will also be instructed to perform 100 training exercises per week for 15 weeks, as a means of applying the information they learn and reducing their cough. The training exercises will also be performed on the website.

Good question! The sham comparator arm in this trial is designed to simulate a treatment condition that provides minimal treatment but is perceived to be effective by the participant. In this arm, participants will have access to five educational and training videos that are approximately 2-5 minutes in length each. They will watch these videos at least once weekly. The videos will educate participants about their cough and the importance of controlling the cough. Participants in this arm will also self-report daily cough frequency. They will be instructed to complete a 6-item questionnaire on their perception of the treatment two weeks and four weeks after the first consultation. This will measure their subjective experience in relation to their cough and satisfaction with the study treatments.

The primary objective of this clinical trial is to determine the efficacy of the Internet-based behavioral intervention for refractory chronic cough by comparing changes in cough severity symptoms at 2- and 12-month follow-up. The sham comparator arm is included so that we can evaluate the effects of the treatment relative to an active comparator intervention. This approach is important because it allows us to account for factors such as study entry criteria, the placebo effect, natural variation in symptoms over time, and the overall impact of repeated assessment and intervention delivery on the cough-related outcomes over time. By considering these factors, we can ensure that changes in cough severity symptoms can be robustly attributed to the active treatment arm. The use of a sham comparator arm is a core component of evidence-based efficacy evaluation and is considered an important factor in study design when determining the best way to compare treatments.

I agree with you. Randomizing participants to either the experimental or sham comparator is an appropriate method to ensure the groups are comparable. This strategy is generally considered to be the gold standard for allocation with the fewest potential biases introduced . One approach to consider is simple 1:1 randomization. This means that for every person who enrolls in the study, the next person to enroll would be in the other group . The advantage of this approach is that groups are randomized in an equal proportion rather than allocating participants in blocks, resulting in more randomness. However, it is important to consider the potential effect of other factors such as the time of the day that you assign the participant to the treatment arm. One approach to improve the randomization strategy is stratified randomization. This means breaking down the enrollment into smaller groups of a more homogenous nature, such as time of day, and then randomly assigning participants within each stratum to either the experimental or placebo intervention .

There will be blinding procedures in place for this trial. Both the participants and the treating health care professionals will be blinded to treatment assignment. To ensure participant and treating healthcare professional blinding, participants will be assigned treatment codes (e.g., Treatment A and Treatment B) rather than treatment type (e.g., Internet-Behavioral Cough Suppression Therapy and sham comparator treatment). Similarly, treating healthcare professionals will only have access to participants' treatment code and treatment codes will be used when contacting treating healthcare professionals to provide information on participant treatment status.

Certainly! The clinical trial is aimed at developing and testing the efficacy of an Internet-based behavioral intervention for refractory chronic cough. A total of 12 arms were proposed, with varying combinations of intervention and masking. The primary outcome measure was weekly cough frequency assessed through online surveys. A power analysis was conducted, and recruitment strategies were discussed. The sample size was estimated to range from 75 to 600, depending on the arm. All 12 arms were found to demonstrate a moderate to large effect size (Cohen's d = 0.63-2.88) on reductions in cough frequency. It was suggested that a randomized single-blind trial with only two arms would maintain integrity while allowing replication and being efficient to execute. The two arms included an experimental arm with an educational component (iBCST) and a sham comparator arm. Participants were randomized to either arm (iBCST or sham).

The IPACK block includes an injection of 15 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine in the gap created between the anterior inferior pelvic nerve, posterior inferior thigh nerve, and posterior approach of the adductor canal below the fascia lata immediately below the inguinal ligament at the middle of the skin crease of the medial thigh.

In addition to the inspiratory positive airway pressure or IPAP, a positive pressure limitation is necessary, either at the end of inspiration or at the beginning of inspiration, or both. When you breathe with a ventilator, the air inflates your lungs at the rate of breathing, which is also called flow. The ventilator has a flow limitation because it limits the amount of air it puts in at once. So, the first arm with 15% expiratory cycling, this study puts a limit on the flow of air on exhaling. The second arm allows 15% expiratory cycling with a positive end inspiratory pressure, or PEEP. In the third arm, the PEEP is 20%. This study examines the effects of allowing short, abrupt bursts of high airflow to come out of the ventilator in a short amount of time. The study compares this to a situation where the ventilator delivers a continuous low flow of air slowly at the end of each breath. The fourth arm will compare PEEP of 20% versus 10%. This study allows some air out of the machine when the person breathes in, and then another positive pressure on the exhale. The aim is to see if releasing that air pressure early on the inhale results in reduced damage or better breathing for the person.

Fantastic! The third arm will be an active control. In this arm, patients will receive pressure support ventilation with 30% expiratory cycling. For the intervention/treatment, we can consider something like passive heating in the form of a warm-water immersion tank, i.e., a bathtub. During the experimental treatment sessions described in the paragraph above, participants are invited to step into a bathtub with warm, filtered, and thermostatically hot water. The temperature will be regulated to 40°C for the entire duration of the 30-minute session since temperatures in the high 30s have been shown to be effective in inducing the effects of heat therapy in past research [104, 105]. Participants are not in water that is 40°C; the temperature in the tub can increase to 40°C due to their body heat. We understand that individuals with high SCI have decreased sensory feedback in the thermoreceptors, so we need to be aware of any discomfort, pain, or even potential injury due to overheating while the individual is engaged in the study. It is also critical to ensure that we meet the safety of the research participants at all times.

Certainly. The reasons for designing the experimental arm with a study group of participants living with a spinal cord injury between T7 and C4 levels who are sedentary to active, at least 2 years post-injury, able to do a level transfer with minimal assistance, and engaged in a regular bowel/bladder management program are to:

For the control group/arm, we can include non-disabled healthy individuals of matched age, weight, and sex. The non-disabled individuals with no spinal cord injury should be able to do a level transfer with no/minimal assistance and have no existing or previous conditions that would affect their blood or core body temperature. These criteria will ensure that the participants in the control group are similar to those with spinal cord injuries to minimize variability due to confounding factors such as age and underlying health conditions.

The inclusion criteria for the experimental arm include: 1) diagnosis of a spinal cord injury at the level of T7-C4 with more than 2 years post-injury, 2) sedentary to active, 3) engaged in a regular bowel/bladder management program, 4) able to do a level transfer with minimal assistance, and 5) no current pain or musculoskeletal contraindications to submerging in a hot tub. The intervention for the experimental arm involves passive heating achieved by immersion in a hot tub at 40 degrees Celsius for approximately 45 minutes.

model_response: Alright, let's go over a few options for a control group. We could have a usual care control group, which would involve administering care according to the usual practice for that setting. For example, a control group for a sleep study might receive no treatment or a placebo, whereas a control group for a pain study might receive standard-of-care pain medications but not an intervention specific to pain management. Alternatively, we could have a control group that receives an active treatment that is intended to be equivalent in effect, and this is sometimes called a sham treatment. For example, in a study on a drug treatment, the investigators could offer a placebo, an inactive look-alike substance. Alternatively, for a behavioral treatment, the control group could be given another active treatment, with effects similar to the intervention of interest. For example, for a study on the effectiveness of music intervention, a control group could be provided with a less complex intervention (e.g., reading) that also has potentially positive effects on patients. And finally, the fourth option for a control group is no treatment or control care. This could be an option for some clinical conditions where treatment is not usually provided in a clinical setting. For studies on interventions to reduce the transmission of infection, placebo and control treatments that are intended to have equivalent effects can be very hard to implement, as it may not be ethical to withhold proven methods of protection from individuals who are at high risk for infection. A control group without treatment might be appropriate if a study intervention is being evaluated in the absence of any proven treatments currently in use (3,4,5).

CET is a negative future thought generation task, where participants envision negative future scenarios, such as imagined relapse. EFT results in the creation of positive future events, whereas CET focuses on negative future events. By directly contrasting CET and EFT, we can gain a better understanding of how EFT affects chronic pain and alcohol use disorder. The addition of LIFU in this study arm will provide control for the effects of the laser therapy, allowing us to determine the extent to which LIFU impacts negative future event generation.

Certainly. The reason the experimental group requires excisional biopsy is because of the specific intervention you wanted to assess clinically. The use of VAE is a recent clinical practice, and it has the potential to completely remove the pathology of interest. VAE is different from traditional biopsy procedures on 2 important levels. Firstly, VAE involves a device that can be attached to a vacuum pump and is specifically designed to collect samples. The use of a specific device that is designed for vacuum pump collection distinguishes it from a traditional biopsy procedure. Secondly, VAE can allow samples to be removed at the rate of 2 to <5 cm3 per minute, whereas traditional biopsies remove samples at the rate of approximately 0.5 cm3 per minute. The difference in sample removal rates can result in a significant amount of additional tissue sampled, which could potentially increase the chances of completely removing the pathology of interest. Therefore, the experimental group of your trial specifically requires excisional biopsy to allow comparison of VAE with non-excisional biopsy methods. The non-excisional biopsy methods may lead to residual disease that can be missed with VAE.

In this clinical trial, participants who have multiple rib fractures and require analgesia would be randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments, using a simple or stratified randomization method: Study Arm 1: Ultrasound-guided Continuous Serratus Anterior Plane Block (CWED)Study Arm 2: Standard care + intravenous dexmedetomidine infusion (dose to be followed by the University's recommendations)

I selected this intervention for the first study arm because it is a regional block that has been shown to be effective in pain management following rib fractures. Additionally, this block has a low risk of complications such as pneumothorax, and can provide analgesia for several days. This is a non-opioid-based analgesia option, which is beneficial for patients at risk of opioid addiction or already undergoing opioid therapy. Based on the previous studies, using this regional block can replace or augment opioid analgesia (Jasani, 2022).

The second arm is the control group: Standard analgesic regimen group (Group C). Patients in this group will only receive standard analgesic drugs, such as paracetamol, ibuprofen, and oxycodone, as used in routine care for patients with multiple rib fractures.

The selection of dexmedetomidine for the second study arm is based on its efficacy in managing moderate to severe pain. Dexmedetomidine is a potent selective agonist of the alpha-2 adrenergic receptor, known for its sedative, anxiolytic, sympatholytic, and analgesic properties. It has become an attractive option for pain management in various patient populations and medical procedures. In addition to its analgesic effects, dexmedetomidine has the added benefit of sedation, which could potentially enhance sleep during the recovery process and minimize opioid-related side effects. Dexmedetomidine infusion has been shown to effectively reduce the postoperative morphine consumption and improve pain control compared to other analgesic treatments. Utilizing dexmedetomidine infusion as a comparator allows us to directly compare its effectiveness with ultrasound-guided continuous SAP block.

Certainly, here are the full study arms:Group SA single intervention group that will receive an ultrasound-guided serratus anterior plane block with bolus 2 mg/kg of LEVO followed by continuous infusion of LEVO at a rate of 0.125% over 48 h in postoperative periodGroup DB single intervention group that will receive intravenous dexmedetomidine infusion with an initial bolus dose followed by continuous infusion in postoperative period over 48 h
